title: Berkshire Hathaway's Coca-Cola Investment (1988)
description: Buffett invested $1 billion in Coca-Cola after the 1987 crash, recognizing the brand moat and global distribution network. The investment grew to over $25 billion.
key_insight: Brand power + global distribution + consumer habit = durable moat. Bought when Mr. Market was depressed.

title: Soros Breaks the Bank of England (1992)
description: George Soros bet $10 billion against the British pound, recognizing the unsustainable peg to the Deutsche Mark. Made $1 billion in a single day.
key_insight: Reflexivity in action - the peg was unsustainable, and betting against it would accelerate its collapse. Asymmetric payoff with limited downside.

title: Long-Term Capital Management Collapse (1998)
description: LTCM's Nobel laureate-led fund collapsed due to excessive leverage and model overconfidence during the Russian debt crisis.
key_insight: Excessive leverage + model overconfidence + fat tail events = catastrophic failure. The models worked until they didn't.

title: Amazon's Long-Term Thinking (1997-2020)
description: Bezos sacrificed short-term profits for long-term market dominance, reinvesting all cash flow into growth and infrastructure.
key_insight: Second-order thinking + network effects + scale economies + long-term compounding = winner-take-most outcome.

title: Enron Fraud and Collapse (2001)
description: Enron's accounting fraud was enabled by incentive misalignment, complexity as camouflage, and authority-misinfluence tendency.
key_insight: Lollapalooza of bad incentives + complexity + authority worship + psychological denial created massive fraud.

title: Munger's See's Candies Investment (1972)
description: Berkshire paid $25 million for See's Candies, learning the power of pricing power and brand loyalty. Generated over $2 billion in pre-tax earnings.
key_insight: Brand power allows pricing power. Capital-light business with high returns on invested capital compounds beautifully.

title: 2008 Financial Crisis - Housing Bubble
description: Systemic failure driven by incentive misalignment, moral hazard, and lollapalooza of psychological tendencies across the financial system.
key_insight: Ultimate lollapalooza: bad incentives + moral hazard + social proof + overoptimism + positive feedback loops = systemic collapse.

title: Bridgewater's All Weather Strategy
description: Ray Dalio designed a portfolio to perform in any economic environment using risk parity principles.
key_insight: Scenario analysis + redundancy + probabilistic thinking = resilient portfolio across economic regimes.

title: Renaissance Technologies Medallion Fund
description: Jim Simons built the most successful hedge fund in history using quantitative methods and pattern recognition.
key_insight: Rigorous probabilistic thinking + Bayesian updating + multidisciplinary approach = sustained alpha generation.

title: Kodak's Failure to Adapt (1975-2012)
description: Kodak invented digital photography but failed to adapt due to inconsistency-avoidance and protecting existing business.
key_insight: Inconsistency-avoidance + status quo bias + creative destruction denial = corporate death.

title: Standard Oil Monopoly Building (1870-1911)
description: Rockefeller built the most powerful monopoly in history through scale economies, vertical integration, and ruthless competition.
key_insight: Scale economies + cost advantages + winner-take-all dynamics = monopoly power. Eventually broken by antitrust.

title: Rothschild Information Advantage at Waterloo (1815)
description: Nathan Rothschild used superior information networks to profit from Napoleon's defeat before others knew the outcome.
key_insight: Information asymmetry + speed of information = massive trading advantage. First-mover advantage in information.

title: Tesla's Vertical Integration Strategy
description: Musk vertically integrated Tesla from batteries to sales, applying first principles thinking to automotive manufacturing.
key_insight: First principles + learning curve + surfing long waves (EV transition) = disruption of legacy automakers.

title: Theranos Fraud (2003-2018)
description: Elizabeth Holmes used authority-misinfluence and social proof to perpetuate a massive healthcare fraud.
key_insight: Authority worship + social proof + psychological denial + information suppression = sustained fraud.

title: Singapore's Economic Transformation (1965-2000)
description: Lee Kuan Yew transformed Singapore from third world to first through pragmatic governance and long-term thinking.
key_insight: Aligned incentives + second-order thinking + strong culture + talent focus = national transformation.

title: Walmart vs Sears (1962-2005)
description: Sam Walton's fanatical execution and cost focus defeated Sears' bureaucratic advantages.
key_insight: Cost advantages + scale + execution excellence beat bureaucratic incumbents. Sears suffered diseconomies of scale.

title: Netflix's Pivot from DVD to Streaming
description: Reed Hastings cannibalized Netflix's DVD business to dominate streaming, avoiding Kodak's fate.
key_insight: Creative destruction of own business + second-order thinking + surfing technology waves = market dominance.

title: Berkshire's GEICO Investment Evolution
description: Buffett first invested in GEICO in 1951, eventually acquiring the whole company in 1996, demonstrating patient capital allocation.
key_insight: Low-cost operator + direct distribution moat + patient compounding = exceptional returns over decades.

title: WeWork Collapse (2019)
description: Adam Neumann's WeWork imploded due to misaligned incentives, excessive self-regard, and unsustainable business model.
key_insight: Excessive self-regard + incentive misalignment + overoptimism + agency problems = spectacular failure.

title: Apple's Ecosystem Lock-In
description: Apple built an ecosystem with massive switching costs, creating one of the most valuable companies in history.
key_insight: Switching costs + network effects + brand power + ecosystem moat = winner-take-most in premium segment.

title: Crassus's Roman Real Estate Empire
description: Marcus Crassus became Rome's richest man by buying burning buildings cheap and using his private fire brigade.
key_insight: Buying when others are panicking (deprival-superreaction) + asymmetric information = wealth accumulation.

title: Koch Industries Market-Based Management
description: Charles Koch built Koch Industries into a $125B conglomerate using principled entrepreneurship and decentralized decision-making.
key_insight: Aligned incentives + talent/trust + strong culture + comparative advantage focus = sustained growth.

title: Dot-Com Bubble (1995-2000)
description: Massive speculation driven by social proof, overoptimism, and lollapalooza of psychological tendencies.
key_insight: Social proof + overoptimism + availability bias + positive feedback = bubble. Munger and Buffett avoided it.

title: Peter Thiel's PayPal Mafia Strategy
description: Thiel built PayPal with contrarian thinking and created a network of founders who went on to build major companies.
key_insight: Network effects + winner-take-all + talent concentration + first principles = platform dominance and talent network.

title: Berkshire's Salomon Brothers Crisis (1991)
description: Munger and Buffett saved Salomon from collapse by restoring integrity after a Treasury bond scandal.
key_insight: Culture as control + transparency (five W's) + cancer surgery (removing bad actors) = crisis resolution.

title: Google's Search Monopoly
description: Google achieved search dominance through superior technology, network effects, and data advantages.
key_insight: Network effects + learning curve + scale economies + information advantage = natural monopoly in search.

title: Lehman Brothers Collapse (2008)
description: Lehman's excessive leverage and risk-taking led to the largest bankruptcy in US history.
key_insight: Excessive leverage + moral hazard + incentive-caused bias + excessive self-regard + nonlinearity = catastrophic failure.

title: Microsoft's Antitrust Battle (1998-2001)
description: Microsoft's monopoly tactics led to antitrust action, demonstrating the limits of winner-take-all strategies.
key_insight: Winner-take-all + network effects can trigger regulatory response. Bureaucracy eventually set in.

title: Buffett's Newspaper Investments
description: Buffett invested heavily in newspapers recognizing local monopolies, but eventually acknowledged the moat was eroding.
key_insight: Even great moats can be destroyed by technology. Creative destruction eventually overcame local monopolies.

title: Dalio's Debt Crisis Framework
description: Ray Dalio developed a systematic framework for understanding debt crises by studying all major ones in history.
key_insight: Multidisciplinary study + scenario analysis + pattern recognition = predictive framework for crises.

title: Franklin's Junto Club
description: Benjamin Franklin created a mutual improvement society that became a model for networking and knowledge sharing.
key_insight: Reciprocation + network effects + curiosity + multidisciplinary approach = compounding knowledge and influence.

title: Seneca's Stoic Wealth Management
description: Seneca became one of Rome's wealthiest men while teaching Stoic philosophy, demonstrating practical wisdom application.
key_insight: Inversion (premeditatio malorum) + scenario planning + resilience + circle of competence = wealth preservation.

title: SpaceX Reusable Rockets
description: Musk applied first principles thinking to reduce launch costs by 10x through reusable rockets.
key_insight: First principles + inversion (why can't rockets be reused?) + learning curve = industry disruption.

title: Berkshire's Dexter Shoe Mistake
description: Buffett's worst investment - paid $433M in Berkshire stock for a company destroyed by foreign competition.
key_insight: Misjudged moat durability + paid with stock (compounding error) + foreign competition. Autopsy learning valuable.

title: Costco's Membership Model
description: Costco built customer loyalty through low margins, high quality, and membership psychology.
key_insight: Cost leadership + switching costs (membership) + reciprocation (value to members) + culture = loyal customer base.

title: Visa/Mastercard Duopoly
description: Payment networks achieved near-monopoly through network effects and switching costs.
key_insight: Two-sided network effects + switching costs + rational duopoly = exceptional returns.

title: Polya's Problem-Solving Method
description: George Polya developed systematic approaches to mathematical problem-solving applicable to all domains.
key_insight: Systematic approach + inversion + multidisciplinary thinking + falsification = better problem solving.

title: Getty's Oil Empire Building
description: J. Paul Getty built an oil empire through contrarian buying during the Depression and patient capital allocation.
key_insight: Mr. Market exploitation + buying during deprival-superreaction + compounding + margin of safety = wealth.

title: FTX Collapse (2022)
description: Sam Bankman-Fried's crypto exchange collapsed due to fraud, misaligned incentives, and lack of controls.
key_insight: Incentive-caused bias + agency problems + excessive self-regard + authority worship + information suppression = fraud.

title: Smil's Energy Transition Analysis
description: Vaclav Smil's rigorous analysis of energy transitions shows they take 50-70 years, not decades.
key_insight: Base rate thinking + multidisciplinary analysis + falsification of optimistic claims = realistic forecasting.

title: Munger's Daily Journal Investment
description: Munger transformed a small newspaper company into a software business, demonstrating adaptability.
key_insight: Creative destruction acceptance + second-order thinking + talent focus + circle of competence = successful pivot.

title: Tulip Mania (1637)
description: First recorded speculative bubble driven by social proof and greater fool theory.
key_insight: Social proof + overoptimism + lollapalooza + positive feedback = bubble. Pattern repeats throughout history.

title: Berkshire's BYD Investment
description: Munger championed BYD investment in 2008, recognizing founder quality and EV potential.
key_insight: Talent assessment + surfing long waves + first principles engineering + margin of safety = 30x return.

title: IBM's Mainframe to Services Transition
description: IBM successfully pivoted from hardware to services under Lou Gerstner, avoiding Kodak's fate.
key_insight: Creative destruction acceptance + cancer surgery (cutting hardware) + culture change = successful transformation.

title: Soros's Reflexivity in Asian Crisis (1997)
description: Soros recognized reflexive dynamics in Asian currency pegs and profited from their collapse.
key_insight: Reflexivity + phase transitions + probabilistic thinking + asymmetric payoffs = crisis profits.

title: Moody's/S&P Rating Agency Failure (2008)
description: Rating agencies gave AAA ratings to toxic securities due to incentive-caused bias.
key_insight: Incentive-caused bias (paid by issuers) + agency problems + authority worship + moral hazard = systemic failure.

title: Berkshire's Insurance Float Strategy
description: Buffett recognized insurance float as free leverage for investment, building a unique competitive advantage.
key_insight: Leverage (float) + compounding + moat (underwriting discipline) + time value of money = structural advantage.

title: Nokia's Smartphone Failure
description: Nokia dominated mobile phones but failed to adapt to smartphones due to organizational dysfunction.
key_insight: Inconsistency-avoidance + bureaucratic inertia + information suppression + status quo bias = disruption death.

title: Thiel's Zero to One Philosophy
description: Peter Thiel's contrarian framework for building monopolies through vertical progress.
key_insight: Winner-take-all focus + first principles + value capture + avoiding crowds = monopoly building.

title: Munger's Wesco Financial Transformation
description: Munger transformed Wesco from a savings and loan into a diversified holding company.
key_insight: Circle of competence + opportunity cost thinking + second-order effects + compounding + talent = transformation.
